column1: The distinction between fluid and crystallized intelligence is important because the two are influenced by different factors. While the former is more biologically determined and genetically predisposed
column2: the latter is shaped more by experience. This is a little bit similar to what we know of sports: some people are more likely to develop stronger muscles than others
column3: but this does not turn them automatically into world-class athletes. Instead
column4: they need many years of training and experience to make it to the top. Likewise
column5: people need to apply their fluid intelligence to a particular domain of knowledge
column6: such as physics or history or neuroscience
column7: to become really good at what they are doing.When it comes to cognition
column8: psychologists speak of a two-component model of cognitive development. By that
column9: they mean that cognition is always a combination of some aspects of fluid intelligence and some aspects of crystallized intelligence
column10: but the two components develop differently across the lifespan. After you are born
column11: your body and brain develop and you become smarter without much effort.
